Hi everyone,

I'm currently working on a test management application which =
aims to 
provide a common, simple to use GUI to execute tests on a multitud=
e 
of test tools. 

There are a few of us developing this application and i=
ts initial 
concept was born out of the need to drive hardware test tools i=
n a 
telecoms lab, so our previous efforts have been to drive these 
hardwa=
re tools (MGTS, DCT & EVO). Though we feel there is scope to 
broaden its u=
se and we aim to develop "interfaces" to control 
software test tools (such=
 as JUnit).

Since the application itself is developed in Java and we alrea=
dy 
have a suite of JUnit tests; we thought writing a JUnit interface 
woul=
d be a good first step. Though before we get too far in to it, 
it would be=
 good to get other peoples views / thoughts on such a 
tool for JUnit?

Wit=
hout going into too much detail, the application would 
effectively provide=
 a web based test management front-end for JUnit 
(i.e. high level test cas=
e creation, execution and results). There 
would be some initial setup, as =
users would need to mirror (either 
manually or by using helper scripts) th=
eir JUnit test / class names 
in our application (so the application knows =
which method / class to 
execute for each test / suite of tests and what to=
 store the result 
against), but once that's done it would just be a case o=
f executing 
all your JUnit tests through our GUI.

If anyone gets a spare =
few minutes, it would be good to get some 
thoughts on what people think ab=
out the general concept? i.e. 
providing a graphical, simple to use test ex=
ecutor / results store 
(including metrics and chart generation) tool for J=
Unit. Do people 
think it will be beneficial?

I'll be more than happy to p=
rovide more information on the 
application etc and we will be looking for =
people to try the system 
(with JUnit) in the New Year.

Cheers,
Les.
